oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Grand Ole Opry - Prince Albert - 1945-11-03 - Part 2
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Part 2 of Prince Albert tobacco sponsored Grand Ole Opry segment from November 3, 1945. Featuring Louie Buck (announcer), and performers Rachel Veach, Pee Wee King and his Golden West Cowboys, Minnie Pearl, Mac McGar, the Duke Of Paducah, and Roy Acuff and his Smoky Mountain Boys (supposedly appearing live from Hollywood, CA. while filming Night Train To Memphis for Republic Pictures, likely a recording). Held at Ryman Auditorium, Nashville, TN.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Rachel Veach; Pee Wee King; Golden West Cowboys; Minnie Pearl; Mac McGar; Roy Acuff; Smoky Mountain Boys; Old Hickory Singers; Duke Of Paducah
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Rachel Veach introduces Pee Wee King and his Golden West Cowboys -- Weary Lonesome Blues (Rachel Veach, Pee Wee King, Golden West Cowboys) -- Louie Buck introduces Minnie Pearl -- Comedy routine (Minnie Pearl) -- Louie Buck introduces Mac McGar -- Dill Pickle Rag (Mac McGar mandolin) -- Louie Buck introduces Roy Acuff -- That Glory Bound Train (Roy Acuff and his Smoky Mountain Boys) -- Prince Albert commercial (Louie Buck) -- Prince Albert jingle (Old Hickory Singers) -- Louie Buck introduces the Old Hickory Singers -- The Little Old Log Cabin In The Lane (Old Hickory Singers) -- Louie Buck introduces the Duke Of Paducah, and Pee Wee King and his Golden West Cowboys -- Arkansas Traveler (Duke Of Paducah calls, Pee Wee King and his Golden West Cowboys) -- Louie Buck talks -- Cindy (Opry cast) -- Closing statement (Duke Of Paducah, Louie Buck) -- War Bonds P.S.A. -- Network announcements
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: WSM (Radio station : Nashville, Tenn.); National Broadcasting Company; Grand ole opry (Radio program); Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Buck, Louis, 1910-1971; Veach, Rachel; King, Pee Wee, 1914-2000; Golden West Cowboys (Musical group); Minnie Pearl; McGar, Mac; Acuff, Roy; Smoky Mountain Boys; Old Hickory Singers; Duke of Paducah, 1901-1986; Boyd, Shorty
